**Intel faces class action lawsuits regarding Meltdown and Spectre**

https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/01/intel-faces-class-action-lawsuits-regarding-meltdown-and-spectre/

Three class action complaints have been filed against Intel over the Meltdown and Spectre CPU security flaws that were discovered by researchers earlier this year and widely publicized earlier this week.

The three lawsuits—filed in California, Indiana, and Oregon (PDF)—cite not just the security vulnerabilities and their potential impact, but also Intel's response time to them. Researchers notified Intel about the flaws in June. Now, Intel faces a big headache. The vast majority of its CPUs in use today are impacted, and more class action complaints may be filed beyond these three.

The three complaints also cite suggestions that devices using Intel's CPUs will see significant slowdown as a result of addressing the security flaws. However, that point is in some dispute. In the course of its various public efforts to mitigate damage and address concerns, Intel has publicly said in a statement that these concerns are overblown:

Intel has begun providing software and firmware updates to mitigate these exploits. Contrary to some reports, any performance impacts are workload-dependent, and, for the average computer user, should not be significant and will be mitigated over time.

Google, whose Project Zero team was involved in the initial discovery of the vulnerabilities, seemed to support Intel's claim when it wrote in its security blog about performance on its devices:

There has been speculation that the deployment of KPTI causes significant performance slowdowns. Performance can vary, as the impact of the KPTI mitigations depends on the rate of system calls made by an application. On most of our workloads, including our cloud infrastructure, we see negligible impact on performance. In our own testing, we have found that microbenchmarks can show an exaggerated impact. Of course, Google recommends thorough testing in your environment before deployment; we cannot guarantee any particular performance or operational impact.

Either way, the costs for Intel after Meltdown and Spectre could be significant. The Guardian consulted sources such as Fort Pitt Capital Group analyst Kim Forrest to paint a picture of what Intel faces. Regardless of the outcome of these class action suits, the paper writes that Intel will likely find itself in a poor bargaining position with its cloud customers and other enterprise partners and that it will likely have to spend more heavily on security in the future.

Some of us are or feel doomed to be physically alone. I wish internet exclusive relationships were more common. If we can forget about the physical barriers between and allow ourselves to fall in love over the internet. Isn't that what we need at our base level as humans, just to somehow close the distance if not physically, then digitally? Take what we can get? Copyright law is an interesting thing. Everything you make is ©(Your Name Here) (Year You Made It) and you determine the licensing terms. Creative Commons, GNU GPL, MIT license, etc. are cookie cutter licenses and may be recognized by the courts. You can create your own license. For instance, I could create a license called IDGAFWYDWTCBDBAA (I Don't Give A Fuck What You Do With This Content But Don't Be An Asshole). You only have to write it out. That's it.

Even though my friends understand why I left their favorite corporation-owned social network, I still feel like I've somehow become irrelevant. My group chat is pretty much dead. It's because of false positives in spam detection that this happened, but we all knew from the very beginning that the social network in question had been and always will be garbage. That doesn't change their destination one bit. That's why I preach that corporations own your friends and family (most of them, anyway). I'd rather feel like these friends and family have become irrelevant, because that would be easier than them forcing me to stay on the platform that would have cut me off from everyone anyway.

I'm wondering what would have happened if Mega Ltd. teamed up with Nofish, and I seriously wonder why this didn't happen, because Kim Dotcom's MegaNet was a very similar if not identical idea. I know Kim got extradited on bullshit charges, but his company lives on... Might it be because that would have attracted the attention of Kim Dotcom's enemies in the US or because Kim went on trial in a corrupt court to inevitably be imprisoned? Development would move fast if companies placed their interest in ZeroNet, but I can see another problem with it: A need to make profit. Though, even mega corporations are now invested in open source technology, so are governments and a handful of good-willed organizations. I bet any adversaries to sovereign nations would also kind of ironically have an interest in such technology, even though it mainly brings people around the world together. You'll never see as many Chinese, Russian, and other nationalities so densely coexisting as here talking about pretty much anything, and that's pretty damn awesome by itself. So, going back to the main point: Why isn't there more interest in this from those packing a ton of money and man power? ZeroNet is a web utopia. All I can think is that this makes every corrupt power shake in their tiny boots, fearing greatly that any action taken for or against ZeroNet will spur a rise in popularity or a Streisand Effect, but the US Navy created and open sourced Tor, so there's that, but I look at militaries as neutral since there are good people who are sometimes commanded/herded by corrupt entities. That stands to further reason as to why I would expect more outside investment into ZeroNet's development. The fucking US Navy at the very least should be in on this, following the reason of them having created Tor. I find it strange that this isn't the case. I can only speculate that ZeroNet is too good for them to give free advertising to it, as explained before.

#**[This favicon generator is the best on the entire planet!](https://realfavicongenerator.net/) See [my ZeroTalk thread](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1538092400_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd) where I describe it.**

Hex color code knowledge: Values are 0-9 and a-f (a-f represent 10-15). 0 represents no addition of color from the digit, so it's just nothing, as you would expect. The digits are arranged in RGB order, so #f00 and #ff0000 are full on red, #0f0 and #00ff00 are full on green, #00f #0000ff is full on blue. With three digits, you might already know now that it's simply RGB. With Six digits, it's RrGgBb. The upper case letters are 1/16 increments. The lower case letters are 1/256 increments. #e00 is 93.33...% full on red, and #ee0000 is 93.33...% full on red. You get that by multiplying the color number value by the corresponding fractions and dividing that by the maximum possible value, then multiplying by 100. With three digit hex, it's simple, because, for instance, if you have **a**, you divide 10 by 15 and that comes out as 66.66...%.  With three digits, 4,096 colors are possible. With six digits, 16,777,216 colors are possible. At least, that's what's I've gathered from my electronics knowledge and toying with hex color codes. You really don't need to know the math though to get it. It's more straightforward than calculation.

If you have background flicker: transform:translate3d(0, 0, 0);
If you have element flicker: backface-visibility:hidden

A few more things: box-shadow should never be applied to a top bar, because this causes poor browser performance, at least if box shadows will ever overlap. margin:0 on body works best for getting rid of the default margins. I think that was another performance choice. Applying backgrounds to body had been problematic for me, so I apply it to html. If you have a border and outline, then you should probably use outline-offset to prevent overlap, because I think this helps with performance a tiny bit.

This helped me. Before looking at 3D accelerating CSS properties, study how to prevent repaints. Chrome does actually respond to CSS transform and other 3D accelerating and 3D efficient properties. The Mozilla article stating otherwise was outdated. I've flip-flopped in confusion, then it started making sense. Even when you could do something two ways, you might find that one is GPU friendly and the other isn't, say for scrolling, so it may be that you can achieve any look just fine, but what's going on when performance is bad is you're not telling the browser the best way to do it. I have no such issue with anyone else's site, but if you need the info, this is chock full of well explained alternatives to get the same exact look and higher performance, then see which element(s) benefit from 3D acceleration and which properties make it lower latency, higher FPS: https://trendyminds.com/blog/silky-css-minimizing-repaints-jank

What if there was a feature where if a site is modified by someone who isn't the site owner, the site code doesn't parse? Probably the most unusual idea ever, but when people question the legality of a blocklist for sites, there are hyperlinks to them. Hyperlinks are the center of attention in many court cases and have been so concerning illegal content. A solution is to disable clicking of a tags. This doesn't mean you can't get the relative addresses in the event that you want to investigate the blocklist's validity in protecting users. You can definitely recreate working URLs. It just sidestep-dodges the first and most common thing that becomes a center of attention: hyperlinks. BTW, Nopelist's hyperlinks are disabled. This is the best compromise I could think of, avoiding becoming opaque to it being reviewed, only being less convenient. So, the feature idea this post starts with prevents restoring hyperlink clicking on the user's device (remember San Andreas's Hot Coffee Mod controversy?), thus you'd have to find where the relative addresses are stored and complete them yourself outside the site manually or use an external script to override the code that disabled hyperlinks. It's a bit of distance from potential defining of liability.

When people want a certain site to exist or change, advocacy for the design is fine, but pestering developers won't help and doesn't effect change, especially throwing ridiculous accusations, and better if you learn how to make a site from scratch or build upon what already exists. Your computer won't explode if you make mistakes as you learn and become more employable as you go. Yes, there are companies that hire for limited skill sets, but don't think you've done it all. Web development standards improve and new web APIs emerge to make it better. Some of what was yesterday's challenge is now today's easy lesson. Don't be afraid to code. If you fear you've messed something up, if your site has peers, you can delete required files if the older versions were published, and the rest might be backed up on proxies. So, say I restructure CSS, JS and HTML and realize I'm going nowhere with an idea or making it worse. I can delete those files, clear the browser cache, then revisit the site to revert to the last published changes. ZeroNet is the most forgiving place to start. I'm not saying you must create a site, but what is there to lose? Heck, people haven't even bothered me and only given praise, probably impressed at what an obsessive newbie had made, so I think people will treat you similarly. In the end, you're making something exactly as you wanted, and that's what matters.

OCD controlled to the point of leisurely applying it for attention to detail while bored: Balancing top and bottom margins of a scrolling list down to .001px... just for one device. Yep, I do that, and it probably doesn't benefit most people, might not be meeting my own insane standard either, probably making it worse until I adjust for other displays, but it's also why I made box and drop shadows blend so well while giving even coverage around corners and sides of an outline. I have too much time, spotting anything microscopically off. I don't know how much of attention to margins is just placebo. I'm pretty sure I notice. This is how I can be. Don't feel sorry. I don't lose my mind over tiles, bricks, and other physical objects. I don't root my phone to "fix" the UI. I let things that aren't mine or are physical be "imperfect." This didn't go well with leveling a motor though, because I only wasted time, going nowhere I needed to, so applying that attention to detail has its limits, but it's not crippling. That's probably why interface design is the better path for me, as physics won't get in the way. Maybe this attention to detail is why I can connect the dots between some things that I have a clue about. You see here I'm trying to justify my OCD. No, I won't apply for quality control on an assembly line. Maybe it's better-suited for things that are mission-critical, like spotting irregularities and contamination of space equipment. I would probably waste too much time obsessing over a standard unit of measurement while not knowing for sure what's exactly right, so I don't think I should bother over some weights and lengths in the real world. IDK. I'm just thinking out loud. "What exactly is it good for besides simpler things?" is all I wonder.

http://planetphotoshop.com/glowing-rusty-text-effect.html Eh, it looks good, but now I kind of feel like for these kinds of things that I've done it all, though I take a **very** long time to end up with a desired texture that isn't toony, and maybe that's the point. Sometimes it can be about getting exactly where you wanted to, and who doesn't want to save time? I've created the look of many different materials, not always on purpose, taking forever to nail any of them and struggling to replicate them from scratch. I could end up underslept. So, when I churned out a bunch of logos for a website, I was called a pro. I responded that I have too much time to burn, fiddling with sliders and dials until it nailed a texture. Half the shit I don't fully understand how it works, like some layer filters take a long time to understand. A pro wouldn't be constantly adjusting everything until it all works out like firing from the hip, would they? And yes, this is another thing I think can be fun to get into if you're bored enough or need a good logo. You can make fantastic designs without being trained nor being a professional. The professional part I imagine would be knowing exactly what you need to do, not burning away a whole day or so on one design, but that doesn't mean practice won't get you there. I didn't get there, but I enjoyed it, maybe too much, but there was determination too. It would be neat if a professional, even if self-described and self-trained, can tell me if I'm right or wrong. This is the latest in my series of posts hoping anyone is inspired to create digital things. A lot of us have gotten into any of these at one point. Amateurs (like me) can pull off professional quality just by being very dedicated to achieving the end result. Maybe you won't feel proud, because computers are extremely forgiving, but people do get impressed. You can be proud. I think that's fine, because it can take a lot to get those results. You have to sink some time no matter what when you start.

First of all, it's not practical to seek out a planet with confirmed life to settle. It's a curiosity, not a need to shake hands and colonize. There's nothing to gain over a lifeless planet that could equally support them. It would be like trying to settle on a particular plain because there is a pride of lions, and that plain might be several hundred more light-years further than an empty meadow.

We would give them diseases and pretend their response is a delusion.

We would lie to them and call it the truth.

We would rape them and tell them they were asking for it.

We would mutilate their genitals.

We would experiment on them.

We would call them predators and put tracking devices on their ankles if they so much as urinate in a bush.

We would bomb their children and call it liberation.

We would try selling them paper like it was precious.

We would take everything they have and call them parasites.

We would threaten their lives and declare ourselves to be their saviours.

We would invade their planet(s) and call them the disease.

If I'm wrong that they won't visit us, if they know what's in store, they would very simply subvert our entire species. If you can make it this far with minimal effort, then you could use that same energy store to sterilize the surface of this planet.

It would most likely be a giant waste of energy and time to fly a ship toward Earth at all.

But... suppose Mars won the lottery for their top pick.

We would have every reason to be afraid and every reason to cure our own species of this illness before that happens. We would have to cautiously approach them like they would have to cautiously approach us, because we don't know if they got this far by being good or as evil as our species can be.

**THE FIVE AGREEMENTS**
**Be Impeccable With Your Word** – Speak with integrity. Say only what you mean. Avoid using the word to speak against yourself or to gossip about others. Use the power of your word in the direction of truth and love.

**Don’t Take Anything Personally** – Nothing others do is because of you. What others say and do is a projection of their own reality, their own dream. When you are immune to the opinions and actions of others, you won’t be the victim of needless suffering.

**Don’t Make Assumptions** – Find the courage to ask questions and to express what you really want. Communicate with others as clearly as you can to avoid misunderstandings, sadness, and drama. With just this one agreement, you can completely transform your life.

**Always Do Your Bes** – Your best is going to change from moment to moment. It will be different when you are healthy as opposed to when you are sick. Under any circumstance, simply do your best, and you will avoid self-judgment, self-abuse, and regret.

**Be Skeptical, But Learn to Liste** – Don’t believe yourself or anybody else. Use the power of doubt to question everything you hear: Is it really the truth? Listen to the intent behind the words, and you will understand the real message.

https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-approves-first-drug-comprised-active-ingredient-derived-marijuana-treat-rare-severe-forms

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration today approved Epidiolex (cannabidiol) [CBD] oral solution for the treatment of seizures associated with two rare and severe forms of epilepsy, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and Dravet syndrome, in patients two years of age and older. This is the first FDA-approved drug that contains a purified drug substance derived from marijuana. It is also the first FDA approval of a drug for the treatment of patients with Dravet syndrome.

CBD is a chemical component of the Cannabis sativa plant, more commonly known as marijuana. However, CBD does not cause intoxication or euphoria (the “high”) that comes from tetrahydrocannabinol (THC).

It is THC (and not CBD) that is the primary psychoactive component of marijuana.

“This approval serves as a reminder that advancing sound development programs that properly evaluate active ingredients contained in marijuana can lead to important medical therapies. And, the FDA is committed to this kind of careful scientific research and drug development,” said FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb, M.D. “Controlled clinical trials testing the safety and efficacy of a drug, along with careful review through the FDA’s drug approval process, is the most appropriate way to bring marijuana-derived treatments to patients. Because of the adequate and well-controlled clinical studies that supported this approval, prescribers can have confidence in the drug’s uniform strength and consistent delivery that support appropriate dosing needed for treating patients with these complex and serious epilepsy syndromes. We’ll continue to support rigorous scientific research on the potential medical uses of marijuana-derived products and work with product developers who are interested in bringing patients safe and effective, high quality products. But, at the same time, we are prepared to take action when we see the illegal marketing of CBD-containing products with serious, unproven medical claims. Marketing unapproved products, with uncertain dosages and formulations can keep patients from accessing appropriate, recognized therapies to treat serious and even fatal diseases.”

Dravet syndrome is a rare genetic condition that appears during the first year of life with frequent fever-related seizures (febrile seizures). Later, other types of seizures typically arise, including myoclonic seizures (involuntary muscle spasms). Additionally, status epilepticus, a potentially life-threatening state of continuous seizure activity requiring emergency medical care, may occur. Children with Dravet syndrome typically experience poor development of language and motor skills, hyperactivity and difficulty relating to others.

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome begins in childhood. It is characterized by multiple types of seizures. People with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome begin having frequent seizures in early childhood, usually between ages 3 and 5. More than three-quarters of affected individuals have tonic seizures, which cause the muscles to contract uncontrollably. Almost all children with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome develop learning problems and intellectual disability. Many also have delayed development of motor skills such as sitting and crawling. Most people with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome require help with usual activities of daily living.

“The difficult-to-control seizures that patients with Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome experience have a profound impact on these patients’ quality of life,” said Billy Dunn, M.D., director of the Division of Neurology Products in the FDA’s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. “In addition to another important treatment option for Lennox-Gastaut patients, this first-ever approval of a drug specifically for Dravet patients will provide a significant and needed improvement in the therapeutic approach to caring for people with this condition.”

Epidiolex’s effectiveness was studied in three randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trials involving 516 patients with either Lennox-Gastaut syndrome or Dravet syndrome. Epidiolex, taken along with other medications, was shown to be effective in reducing the frequency of seizures when compared with placebo.

The most common side effects that occurred in Epidiolex-treated patients in the clinical trials were: sleepiness, sedation and lethargy; elevated liver enzymes; decreased appetite; diarrhea; rash; fatigue, malaise and weakness; insomnia, sleep disorder and poor quality sleep; and infections.

Epidiolex must be dispensed with a patient Medication Guide that describes important information about the drug’s uses and risks. As is true for all drugs that treat epilepsy, the most serious risks include thoughts about suicide, attempts to commit suicide, feelings of agitation, new or worsening depression, aggression and panic attacks. Epidiolex also caused liver injury, generally mild, but raising the possibility of rare, but more severe injury. More severe liver injury can cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, anorexia, jaundice and/or dark urine.

Under the Controlled Substances Act (CSA), CBD is currently a Schedule I substance because it is a chemical component of the cannabis plant. In support of this application, the company conducted nonclinical and clinical studies to assess the abuse potential of CBD.

The FDA prepares and transmits, through the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, a medical and scientific analysis of substances subject to scheduling, like CBD, and provides recommendations to the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) regarding controls under the CSA. DEA is required to make a scheduling determination.

The FDA granted Priority Review designation for this application. Fast-Track designation was granted for Dravet syndrome. Orphan Drug designation was granted for both the Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome indications.

The FDA granted approval of Epidiolex to GW Research Ltd.

The FDA, an agency within the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, protects the public health by assuring the safety, effectiveness, and security of human and veterinary drugs, vaccines and other biological products for human use, and medical devices. The agency also is responsible for the safety and security of our nation’s food supply, cosmetics, dietary supplements, products that give off electronic radiation, and for regulating tobacco products.

It can be invasive, so only plant this where it can't escape.

It looks like a moss, but it's a plant.

Its name is scleranthus biflorus. It's native to Australia and New Zealand.

It's often used as ground cover as it grows only a few inches thick and spreads wide.

Scleranthus biflorus is preferred over scleranthus uniflorus for its vivid green color and density.

*This Bible database is built on technology called ZeroNet. It is designed to be highly censorship resistant and redundant. ZeroNet is designed to have redundant storage, local replication, and erasure coding. This ensures the data is available even if there are node dropouts or data loss. ZeroNet sites cannot be 'taken down' by any one authority. Data on ZeroNet is stored throughout the network without vulnerable central hubs or a single point of failure. Because ZeroNet is using a fully decentralized peer-to-peer network it is also resilient against DDoS attacks as opposed to any centralized system.*

I think what I've said about compiling for ZeroNet dependencies was wrong. First off, Linux Mint 20.2 compiles the libraries just fine and it's 64-bit only. ZeroNet.py runs just fine. It seems that Linux Mint Debian Edition was the problem. If I can get the TOR v3 patch installed for the user-compiled ZeroNet bundle, then I'll be switching to it instead of using the precompiled bundle.

For some reason, signing and publishing with the precompiled bundle via commands requires root... at least with LMDE anyway. I should test everything out on Linux Mint 20.2 and see if that doesn't require root.

Edit: root is still required for the pre-compiled bundle.

I guess the lesson here is that LMDE is not great for a few very important reasons. I thought it was a rolling release and I've been told that it isn't anymore. It has 32-bit support, but you rarely need that, say for Kega Fusion, but little else.

Stick with what's tried and true, like distributions based on Ubuntu, Arch, etc., not experimental distributions like LMDE. You'll have too many very inconvenient, function-breaking bugs with LMDE concerning the user-compiled bundle.

@Piloth: I get the viewpoint. To suppose that corporations would suddenly become a bastion of free speech is indeed ironic. What isn't is that sometimes what is done to improve security opens an opportunity for free speech to prevail by one means or another through a side channel of internet communication, not in any way that uses big tech services, but to take advantage of how their services work. It's like if I and other people standardize making our faces obscured from cameras. The employment is selfish ("I'm doing this for myself" mindset), but the technique benefits others who take advantage of it, and that benefits the initial user. Sometimes, the more people do the same, the better it becomes. If I were the only one using anti-papparazi clothing and face paint, I would be easily singled out, but the greater number of people doing it means I'm harder to single out. This would of course put pressure on camera manufacturers to apply better CCDs or new techniques, but for a time, it's better than nothing and will make attempts to thwart the security more narrow and more expensive. Security is about staying ahead of the curve yourself, not asking big tech to guard you. I get that.

@Moor: GPLv2 if I remember correctly wasn't meant for what Linux uses it for, such as allowing binary blobs to be used with it, but for Linux it worked out in gaining it popularity and support by hardware makers and application developers who wish to jealously guard their code. I don't remember it all, but the short of it is that some licenses have turned out to be different than the authors intended through lack of say one way or another on particular actions. I'm not an expert by any means. I'd pursue a bar license to defend libre software if I were. I only have a general understanding of what had or could happen to licenses with the details mostly forgotten. This comment contains all of such. :/

@Collect238: Without a license you have all rights reserved copyright (unless it expires well after you're dead), which is 100% restrictive without proof of permission by the author while the copyright stands. By default, copyright law restricts everyone except for the author from reusing their work. That's why all open source projects choose or create a license or officially state something like a public domain license, and this is why some of these licenses have to explicitly state "no rights reserved" or some other way to say there's full freedom for everyone to do anything with the code.

@Collect238: Without freely licensing your artwork, everyone assumes they don't have permission by default to do anything with it, because that's how the law concerning it works. I could sue anyone who photocopies my paintings without my permission while the copyright stands, because they were never freely licensed. Your baby foot painting is copyrighted for your entire life +70 years in the US. Laws might be different where you are if you don't live here, but it doesn't change with nations that agree to uphold them in any way such as extradition and trade agreements. It's the evil that is resisted by open licensing.

@Collect238: I'll say now allowing cloning at any time is a pass to copy site code and default assets, but it is weird to think of in context of ©. It's just different than for instance granting permission individuall or permanently to everyone. You know the explanation I have given. Licences are liberties to reproduce the content for individual use. That's the way things are. It's why ZeroNet has a free software license.

However, ZeroNet and IPFS both look like they fill the allotted storage and decide when unpinned files must be deleted to make room. IPFS goes by last accessed and ZeroNet goes by most seeded.

Pinning is a manual task and to my knowledge you can pin a node on IPFS like helping distribute all files on a site.

IPFS is fundamentally different only for the fact that the PubSub thing seems rather new and IPNS is problematic. It's not easy to use with every hobbyist programmer's version as some are adding GUI and implementong OS APIs while others aren't, but IDK if on desktop that's the case. You should get an API page to do everything on, like less friendly ZeroHello, but it's not problematic. So, what I see here is a difference in user friendliness... and that won't be forever. Both are making improvements there.

The important difference is that IPFS is like BitTorrent with some improvements, and knowing ZeroNet doesn't fingerprint and version files the exact same, there are use cases where functioning like IPFS might be great, not always better but a good option, but yeah, IPFS needs support for multiple hop tunneling like TOR and i2p.

And in the end they don't need to merge on a hybrid protocol at all, but that might make an even larger network. It's a perfect world pipe dream, I guess, but users of both will make similar demands as there had been a few common features and points of user friendliness made from within both of their go-to forum communities, so either way I think both will become very similar with slight differences in how they let go unpinned files and sites or nodes to make space for new files.

The first comments I'm thinking were talking about Blocklists. Blocklists are similar between them. IDK if you can choose not to double hash blocked content on IPFS, but on ZeroNet it's an option to double hash the site addresses.
At this point I think you see that what each does differently can be complementary to the other. The differences aren't very strong and yet they aren't  the exact same either.

Delete ZeroNet.conf if you ever mess up configuration. The file will be recreated next time you start ZeroNet. Back up users.json as it has your identity and it's unrecoverable if lost or deleted unless it's still in the recycle bin. Back up your Data folder if you don't want to redownload everything in the event that you can't fix a problem and resort to reinstalling ZeroNet.

What @Version: said are the two most important, your ID and list of connected sites. If you only back those up, you can recover, just more slowly. The two files are quite small. The Data folder has everything including all the files you've downloaded, so that video and those pictures you really like remain instead of requiring redownload.

@Bussdee: The HTML: **<video src="Bussdee Remix.mp4"></video>** and then add style in CSS. You could use the CSS selector **video{*to-list-properties:here;placing-semicolons:between-and;closing-with:right-bracket*}** Those aren't actual properties, but an explanation of how you would lay actual ones out. You can have line breaks and spaces between them, but for values, I believe spaces are required, or else **padding:0055px *and* fixedno-repeat** probably wouldn't be read correctly by the browser. You can add specifity to selectors, such as jpg files under a div class and you can apply the same properties to multiple selectors. If you didn't know that, this will take further explanation. I search for these solutions a lot, but they do take time and some properties require additional properties to work with certain selected elements, because they may be online, block, or inline-block elements and have to be changed with the display CSS property or the HTML element needs to be changed. *Span* and *a* are inline and *div* is block.

I forgot to mention that in the video tag you'll need **controls="controls"** or you can use the anchor tag around an img tag: **** If you use an anchor tag around an img tag, then I recommend using the **img** selector in CSS.

Now for a more specific selector: **.list img[src$='.jpg']{** This sets enclosed properties to work only on jpg images under an element with **class="list"** If you swap **.list** for **#list** it will select for **id="list"** Note that you can only use **id="list"** or whatever id on only one element per page while classes can be used on multiple elements.
@Bussdee: That's what I ended up going with for my site. Overall, it's a nicer look and functionality.
